title: How to play through an entire song with an instrument without forgetting parts of it - Quora

response.answer_text: Bear with me. I have an analogy that applies, I hope. I knew a man when I was in grad school, who always found a way to brag about something in spite of the obvious facts that the rest of us could plainly see. During a Xmas break, a few of us were in the office and my advisor came in and asked us all to come play basketball. I’m from Indiana. It’s in our blood. Like many Hoosiers, I had played the game since I was 4 years old. We took the court, and this man began talking about how he didn’t really ever play, but while others played, he practiced the half court shot, and he was an expert at it. When we were done playing, (and, by the way, he was miserable throughout the scimmage), he walked out to half court, and took about 10 shots. When one went in, he puffed out his chest and strutted around like the peacock we all knew he was. I asked for the ball and, I swear this is true, I made 5 shots in a row. I didn’t say anything to him, except, “When all those other guys were playing, and you were practicing your half court shot, I was playing with them.” Now, how does that apply to your question? Well, stop worrying about playing one song perfectly. Just play. In time, you will be able to understand what playing is all about and you’ll have thousands of songs that you will be able to play all the way through without making any glaring errors, including a few songs you never practiced at all before. Just PLAY! One small footnote here: I have tried a few hundred times to replicate the 5 consecutive shots, and never did it again. I have gotten to 3 fairly often, but never 5. I bask in my good fortune, however, that it happened on the perfect occasion.

Break the song down into its parts: intro, verse, chorus, bridge, etc. Now, instead of tackling a whole song, just tackle a section. You’ll find that, many times, the intro is actually a segment of the verse or chorus. And once you’ve learned the verse structure, it usually is the same for all the verses. Many of the sections are going to be similar. As noted in other answers, once you learn a segment, play it over and over again. You’ll also discover that many solos are based on patterns. Popular music is based on “hooks,” which can be a lyric, a melody, or a solo riff. They’re meant to be memorable, so they’re repeated. (Listen to the end of “Hotel California” for the dueling guitars. Listen to the sax on “Baker Street.”) Once you learn to dissect a song, you’ll find that the pieces themselves aren’t so ovewhelming.
